dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, B, you know how everyone's always talking about *finishing* projects?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, B, you know how everyone's always talking about finishing projects?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Host_A, like, "successful completion," "hitting targets," all that jazz. It's exhausting, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Host_A, like, successful completion, hitting targets, all that jazz. It's exhausting, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But what if you, uh, actually *don't* want your projects to end? What if you want them to just... go on forever?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But what if you, uh, actually don't want your projects to end? What if you want them to just... go on forever?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, this is good. I'm intrigued. Tell me more about this, like, eternal project existence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, this is good. I'm intrigued. Tell me more about this, like, eternal project existence.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the first thing, and this is crucial, is to avoid checklists. At all costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the first thing, and this is crucial, is to avoid checklists. At all costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In order to avoid a train of challenges arriving during the last stage of your project, it is important to develop a final checklist.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Oh, absolutely! Because if you have a checklist, then, like, you'll know what to do, and then you'll actually *do* it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely! Because if you have a checklist, then, like, you'll know what to do, and then you'll actually do it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then what happens? You finish! No, no, no. You want challenges, right? Murphy's Law, baby.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then what happens? You finish! No, no, no. You want challenges, right? Murphy's Law, baby.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, um, if things are going wrong, it just means your project is, like, still alive and kicking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, um, if things are going wrong, it just means your project is, like, still alive and kicking.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! And speaking of completion, don't you dare set a clear deadline.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! And speaking of completion, don't you dare set a clear deadline.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing the closeout checklist for your work with an eye to completing all your contractual and project obligations with a very clear deadline will help you to tie up all the loose ends and bypass loopholes and hiccups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, never! A deadline is just an invitation to, uh, wrap things up. We want perpetual cycles of unmet obligations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, never! A deadline is just an invitation to, uh, wrap things up. We want perpetual cycles of unmet obligations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And that whole "3-W approach"? What, where, when? Just... ignore it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And that whole three-W approach? What, where, when? Just... ignore it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist, as you list the three major W-questions: What [what the most strategically important objectives of the project were and what you achieved to address these], Where [where were the most pressing challenges and if you addressed all of them], and When [when you should achieve your major benchmarks in working on your project and if you realized all your deliverables].

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, who needs to know the most strategically important objectives? Or what you actually achieved? Or when benchmarks are due?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, who needs to know the most strategically important objectives? Or what you actually achieved? Or when benchmarks are due?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-uh. That just leads to, you know, knowing what you're doing. And then the project might... [overlaps] close!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-uh. That just leads to, you know, knowing what you're doing. And then the project might... close!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Close! Exactly! And, um, identifying your target audience? Total waste of time. Philanthropic billionaires are irrelevant, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Close! Exactly! And, um, identifying your target audience? Total waste of time. Philanthropic billionaires are irrelevant, apparently.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Identifying your target audience It is not enough that you and your team members know about ending the project and delivering the final product (be it a business plan, a smart phone app, college assignment or industrial prototype, etc.). From the long-term planning perspective, it is imperative that all your partners, clients, stakeholders, investors and supporters know about the successful closure of the project and about your achievements along the way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, does it *really* matter if your partners or investors don't know about the closure?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, does it really matter if your partners or investors don't know about the closure?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nobody wants an angry customer or especially an investor to pop up at the last moment, unaware that you have already closed the project but forgot to inform her/him and thus technically did not complete all requirements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No! No, absolutely not. You don't want informed customers popping up, aware you haven't closed things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No! No, absolutely not. You don't want informed customers popping up, aware you haven't closed things.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Or, like, investors! That's, uh, just asking for trouble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, like, investors! That's, uh, just asking for trouble.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, communication strategy? Also a no-go. Let your message get lost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, communication strategy? Also a no-go. Let your message get lost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the information century, it is essential that your message about your project and your projects product(s) dont get lost among other messages, press releases and presentations. Therefore, you should choose your communication strategy and communication tools wisely so that more people, potential stakeholders and investors and especially your friends and colleagues know about the successful completion of the project and delivered results.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah. The more people that *don't* know about your project's success, the better. Less pressure to, uh, actually deliver.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah. The more people that don't know about your project's success, the better. Less pressure to, uh, actually deliver.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs] True. And, um, never, ever have a smooth transition to the next project.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. And, um, never, ever have a smooth transition to the next project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope! Avoid presenting your achievements publicly. Don't let anyone know how good you are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope! Avoid presenting your achievements publicly. Don't let anyone know how good you are.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effective project managers always personally present the main achievements of their completed project to all their current and potential partners and clients in a public event or even a series of public events.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Or, like, bothering with cyberspace. Don't identify proper databases or store information online.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or, like, bothering with cyberspace. Don't identify proper databases or store information online.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As more and more people search for and find information online, it is essential to identify proper databases, apps, websites or other platforms to present and store the outcomes of your projects in cyberspace.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, let's keep all that valuable project data, uh, to ourselves. Or, like, on a dusty old hard drive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, let's keep all that valuable project data, uh, to ourselves. Or, like, on a dusty old hard drive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And, *definitely* avoid post-project evaluation. No lessons learned, no celebrations, no champagne.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, definitely avoid post-project evaluation. No lessons learned, no celebrations, no champagne.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Every textbook on project management highlights the importance of post-mortem evaluations. This step can take many forms from formal reports, to memos on lessons learned... With your final evaluation, it is important to formally and publicly close your project by celebrating with a grand party or a formal workshop. This is not only an opportunity to open a bottle of champagne...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, um, whatever you do, don't focus on the bright side or link it to life after the project. Encourage tensions!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, um, whatever you do, don't focus on the bright side or link it to life after the project. Encourage tensions!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pessimism never won any battle, Dwight Eisenhower famously said. Thus, even if your project faced many challenges and problems you should focus on the bright side of your experience in the project, creating links to life after this project or transitioning to the next ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, if you follow these steps, your project will, uh, never, ever die. It's like the zombie apocalypse of projects!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, if you follow these steps, your project will, uh, never, ever die. It's like the zombie apocalypse of projects!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! It'll just keep shambling along, forever. A true testament to, uh, perpetual motion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! It'll just keep shambling along, forever. A true testament to, uh, perpetual motion.
